review.title: The Dynamic Controllability of Conditional STNs with Uncertainty
review.abstract: Recent attempts to automate business processes and medical-treatment processes have uncovered the need for a formal framework that can accommodate not only temporal constraints, but also observations and actions with uncontrollable durations. To meet this need, this paper defines a Conditional Simple Temporal Network with Uncertainty (CSTNU) that combines the simple temporal constraints from a Simple Temporal Network (STN) with the conditional nodes from a Conditional Simple Temporal Problem (CSTP) and the contingent links from a Simple Temporal Network with Uncertainty (STNU). A notion of dynamic controllability for a CSTNU is defined that generalizes the dynamic consistency of a CTP and the dynamic controllability of an STNU. The paper also presents some sound constraint-propagation rules for dynamic controllability that are expected to form the backbone of a dynamic-controllability-checking algorithm for CSTNUs.

sections.heading: Related Temporal Networks
sections.text: This section summarizes three types of temporal networks from the literature: Simple Temporal Networks, Conditional Simple Temporal Problems, and Simple Temporal Networks with Uncertainty. For simplicity, we replace the Conditional Simple Temporal Problem with an equivalent alternative: the Conditional Simple Temporal Network.

sections.heading: Simple Temporal Networks
sections.text: Definition 1 (STN). (Dechter, Meiri and Pearl 1991) A simple temporary network (STN) is a pair, (T, C) where T is a set of real variables, called time points, and C is a set of binary constraints, called simple time constraints. Any constraint in C has the form Y − X ≤ δ, where X and Y are arbitrary time points in T and δ is an arbitrary real number. A solution for STN (T, C) is a complete mapping to the variables in T that meet all constraints in C.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text: The semantics of dynamic controllability for CSTNUs also generalizes the associated terms for CSTPs and STNUs. The motivation for this work was to create a framework for the time constraints that underlie business and medical treatment workflows. In future work, we want to show that each workflow is historically controllable depending on if and only if its underlying CSTNU is dynamically controllable.
